turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Acanthoxyla inermis.
turn.1: What is known about the species Acanthoxyla inermis?
turn.2: Acanthoxyla inermis Acanthoxyla inermis (the unarmed stick insect) is an insect that was described by John Tenison Salmon 1955. " Acanthoxyla inermis" is included in the genus Acanthoxyla, and family Phasmatidae.
turn.5: What is the habitat of the species?
turn.6: This species is native to New Zealand but has been unintentionally moved to Great Britain where it has grown a stable population and is the longest insect observed, and the most common of the stick insects that have established themselves on the island. "A. inermis" has a long thin body and three pairs of thin jointed limbs resembling the foliage.
turn.7: What is the behavior of the species?
turn.8: The species has been observed as having many superficial differences in appearance among individuals: The body colour and texture is varied and is many shades green, brown or yellow.
turn.9: How long is the average length of the species?
turn.10: Adult members of this species can grow to 10 cm long.
turn.11: What other characteristics are there about the species?
turn.12: The bodies of this genus are sometimes covered in spines while other specimens have perfectly smooth bodies and others still have a series of tubercles.
